title: Your First SELECT Query
description: Learn the basics of retrieving data from a database using SELECT and FROM.
instructions: Write a query to select all columns from the employees table.
solution: SELECT * FROM employees
hints: Use SELECT * to select all columns
Use FROM to specify the table name
The format is: SELECT * FROM table_name

tests.description: Query must use SELECT and FROM

title: Selecting Specific Columns
description: Learn how to select specific columns instead of all columns.
instructions: Write a query to select only the name and salary columns from the employees table.
solution: SELECT name, salary FROM employees
hints: Replace the * with specific column names
Separate column names with commas
Format: SELECT column1, column2 FROM table_name

tests.description: Query must select only name and salary

title: Using Column Aliases
description: Learn how to rename columns in your results using aliases.
instructions: Select the name column and rename it to 'employee_name' in the results.
solution: SELECT name AS employee_name FROM employees
hints: Use the AS keyword to create column aliases
Format: SELECT column_name AS alias FROM table
The AS keyword is optional but recommended for readability

tests.description: Query must use alias for name column

title: Removing Duplicates
description: Learn how to get unique values using DISTINCT.
instructions: Write a query to get all unique departments from the employees table.
seedData:
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS employees;
CREATE TABLE employees (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  department TEXT NOT NULL,
  salary INTEGER NOT NULL,
  hire_date TEXT
);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
  (1, 'John Smith', 'Engineering', 95000, '2020-01-15'),
  (2, 'Jane Doe', 'Marketing', 75000, '2019-03-20'),
  (3, 'Bob Johnson', 'Sales', 85000, '2021-06-10'),
  (4, 'Alice Williams', 'Engineering', 110000, '2018-11-05'),
  (5, 'Charlie Brown', 'Marketing', 68000, '2022-02-28');
solution: SELECT DISTINCT department FROM employees
hints: Use DISTINCT before the column name
DISTINCT removes duplicate rows from results
Format: SELECT DISTINCT column FROM table

tests.description: Query must use DISTINCT

title: Basic Limit
description: Learn how to limit the number of rows returned.
instructions: Write a query to select only the first 2 employees from the table.
seedData:
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS employees;
CREATE TABLE employees (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  department TEXT NOT NULL,
  salary INTEGER NOT NULL,
  hire_date TEXT
);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
  (1, 'John Smith', 'Engineering', 95000, '2020-01-15'),
  (2, 'Jane Doe', 'Marketing', 75000, '2019-03-20'),
  (3, 'Bob Johnson', 'Sales', 85000, '2021-06-10'),
  (4, 'Alice Williams', 'Engineering', 110000, '2018-11-05'),
  (5, 'Charlie Brown', 'Marketing', 68000, '2022-02-28');
solution: SELECT * FROM employees LIMIT 2
hints: Use LIMIT at the end of your query
LIMIT specifies the maximum number of rows to return
Format: SELECT * FROM table LIMIT n

tests.description: Query must use LIMIT

title: Basic WHERE Clause
description: Learn how to filter rows using the WHERE clause.
instructions: Write a query to select all employees who work in the 'Engineering' department.
solution: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE department = 'Engineering'
hints: Use WHERE after the table name
Text values must be in single quotes
Format: SELECT * FROM table WHERE column = 'value'

tests.description: Query must filter by Engineering department

title: Numeric Comparisons
description: Learn how to filter with numeric comparison operators.
instructions: Write a query to find all employees with a salary greater than 80000.
solution: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE salary > 80000
hints: Use the > operator for greater than
You can also use >=, <, <= for comparisons
Numeric values don't need quotes

tests.description: Query must filter by salary > 80000

title: Multiple Conditions with AND
description: Learn how to combine multiple conditions using AND.
instructions: Find all employees in Engineering with salary greater than 100000.
solution: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE department = 'Engineering' AND salary > 100000
hints: Use AND to combine conditions
Both conditions must be true for a row to be included
Format: WHERE condition1 AND condition2

tests.description: Query must use AND for both conditions

title: Using IN Operator
description: Learn how to use IN for cleaner multiple value matching.
instructions: Rewrite the previous query using IN to find employees in 'Engineering' or 'Marketing'.
seedData:
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS employees;
CREATE TABLE employees (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  department TEXT NOT NULL,
  salary INTEGER NOT NULL,
  hire_date TEXT
);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
  (1, 'John Smith', 'Engineering', 95000, '2020-01-15'),
  (2, 'Jane Doe', 'Marketing', 75000, '2019-03-20'),
  (3, 'Bob Johnson', 'Sales', 85000, '2021-06-10'),
  (4, 'Alice Williams', 'Engineering', 110000, '2018-11-05'),
  (5, 'Charlie Brown', 'Marketing', 68000, '2022-02-28');

solution: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE department IN ('Engineering', 'Marketing')

title: Pattern Matching with LIKE
description: Learn how to search for patterns using LIKE.
instructions: Find all employees whose name starts with 'J'.
solution: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE name LIKE 'J%'
hints: Use % as a wildcard for any characters
J% means starts with J, followed by anything
Use %J% to find J anywhere in the text

tests.description: Query must use LIKE with pattern

title: NULL Values - IS NULL
description: Learn how to find NULL values using IS NULL.
instructions: Find all employees who don't have a hire_date recorded.
starterCode: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE hire_date = NULL
solution: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE hire_date IS NULL
hints: You cannot use = with NULL
Always use IS NULL or IS NOT NULL
NULL represents missing or unknown data

tests.description: Query must use IS NULL

title: NOT NULL Values
description: Learn how to find non-NULL values using IS NOT NULL.
instructions: Find all employees who have a hire_date recorded.
solution: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE hire_date IS NOT NULL
hints: Use IS NOT NULL to find rows with values
This is the opposite of IS NULL
Useful for finding complete records

tests.description: Query must use IS NOT NULL

title: Basic Sorting - ORDER BY
description: Learn how to sort results using ORDER BY.
instructions: Select all employees and sort them by name alphabetically.
solution: SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY name
hints: ORDER BY goes at the end of your query
Default sort is ascending (A-Z)
Numbers sort from lowest to highest by default

tests.description: Query must use ORDER BY

title: Descending Order
description: Learn how to sort in descending order.
instructions: Select all employees and sort them by salary from highest to lowest.
starterCode: SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY salary
solution: SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY salary DESC
hints: Use DESC for descending order
Use ASC for ascending order (explicit)
DESC comes after the column name

tests.description: Query must use ORDER BY DESC
